comments.commentBody: You mean in NYC. Here in my Midwestern leafy suburban paradise ( as Sun-times columnist Neil Steinberg calls em) city sidewalk plows do the work for us.
This constituent, among many others, wishes Israel would shut up and go away and leave my country alone.

Wow! If I didn't know any better, I would have thought these clueless Republicans, and a few Democrats worried about their re-election prospects (hard to get elected if you do not applaud AIPAC) were cheering their own President! Why don't they just declare Bibi our president and commander-in-chief, and give him keys to our treasury and our nuclear launch codes! Hey, it is not their sons and daughters, who are going to be killed in a war declared for the USA by Bibi!

i notice that the favorite pastime of politicians in this country, more consistently the conservatives, is projection. so now we see that things are the same in israel. what ever they say their enemy is doing? they are already doing in spades.
Or sidewalk plows. Has no one in New York ever seen a sidewalk plow? Where I live the city owns several and the city not individual owners do the work.

This speech has been presented as Boehner inviting Netanyahu. I believe it's much the reverse, that Netanyahu let him know he wanted to speak and Boehner doesn't have the courage to stand up to him.

Netanyahu is just lying when he says it's not political. The whole thing was politically driven. He had nothing new, just the same regurgitation of inaccurate facts he's been giving us since the 1990s.

If this doesn't unite Americans to tear down Citizens United than maybe nothing will.  Here you have the U.S. Congress pimping for AIPAC, and Sheldon Adelson along with a foreign leader that we bankroll, who does absolutely nothing in Isreal to secure real peace and who dares to blatantly disrespect our President, and America and the integrity of our entire foreign intelligence community.  This is disgraceful.

Agreed. All you have to do is read South Carolina's ordinance of secession (in its entirety, not the expurgated versions), and the statement by Alexander Stephens (VP of the Confederacy) on the rationale for succession. But the revisionists, dead-enders, and not-so-closeted bigots know that if they thump the "state's rights" tub long enough and hard enough, many people will keep on believing it.
every time there's an article about the civil war the lost causers emerge from their dark places and sully the conversations.

It's interesting that Lincoln identified slavery as the primary cause of the war-which it was-and just as disingenuous of post-war southerners, (and some current unreconstructed ones) claiming it was only about "states-rights". Many of the rebel states own declarations of secession came right out and announced it as the reason they were seceding, precisely because of what's Lincoln's election represented to them. The politically correct sounding "states rights" claim was just bunch of "spin"-both then and now, to cover up the more insidious reasons they sought disunion in the first place.

Whatever happened to partisanship ended at the waters edge? Its truly disgraceful that politicians can't rise above their own political self-interest when it comes to such grave matters.  I'm ashamed of my country.  And I truly believe the sun is setting on America.

Yes, wake up, America!  Understand that Israel's fate is our fate.  If/when Israel is annihilated with an Iranian nuclear bomb, Iran will come after the other "Great Satan"-- the United States.  Wake up, America, indeed.

Expecting our young people (probably not your sons/daughters) to fight a war against Iran for the sake of the right-wing, the settlers, those who don't want to live in peace/equality with their neighbors, is wrong. Find a way to make a just, lasting peace.
See this is the thing.  Israel's fate is not our fate.  Israel and the US are two separate states with two peoples who do not share the same values or outlooks on everything, including Iran.
Shameful hubris. Fomenting war. Wake up, America.
As far as I am concerned, Israel is now the property of the Republican party.  My support for it has evaporated.

Barack Obama is perfectly capable of humiliating himself.  Obama doesn't need the staunch leadership of Bibi Netanyahu to completely expose himself (Obama) as the corrupt, incompetent "leader" of a naive country that doesn't understand the hostility from every side that Israel faces every day.

To anyone who attended this circus and applauded the foreign leader so that our duly elected president and commander-in-chief could be humiliated:
"Sir/madam, Have you no shame?"

I'm not sure what the US would have done after Europe and Asia were truly bled out from years of fighting, trade with whoever was left?

Germans and Soviets were really nice people, maybe we should have let them have all of continental Europe? In Asia, the Japanese were awful; they made our racists look like saints by comparison.

If you would rather watch the world enslaved than fight for freedom, say so, but World War II was worth fighting.

Why do you Democrats TRUST the Iranians to do what they will willingly agree to with Obama, who will be out of office when they build their first nuclear bomb? They already have the missles to deliver it right on Tel Aviv.

Well, since Boehner and none of the other Congresspeople are aliens, I assume you are proposing that we apply the Logan Act to BiBi.  And "deport" a foreign head of state.  Who doesn't live here in the first place.  I must admit:  I didn't see that one coming

"Sorry, and peace to Israel."

There will be no peace in Israel as long as Iran continues to enrich uranium in order to make bombs to annihilate Israel. That's what you don't seem to understand.

well, well, reading the comments here, it seems Mr. Netanyahu invites so much anti-Israeli rhetoric, that Israeli voters might take a hint.

A powerful speech, though the heart goes to Israel, when its people are relying essentially on about one friend in the world to protect itself from the hatred around it, one cannot not see how politicized some of the characterizations are that N. gave. Really, was a secular regime so bad in Syria? Really, is a popular revolution in Yemen something out-right bad?
Painting Iran as a caricature character makes N. himself look one-dimensional. Presuming that Israel has the right to tell American president and policy makers in such an open manner what to do with Iran is just a big huge faux pas. Sorry, and peace to Israel.

How about the sidewalks around City parks and other government properties which in my neighborhood are often not cleaned? Neighborhood residents should be able to sue the City and get a refund of their tax monies for these situations.

"Could be a big puddle" has already become "IS a big, big puddle."  Just back from walking my dog around the block.  It would have been our usual longer walk to Washington Square Park however I neglected to bring an inflatable raft and oars to not only cross the street but to simply navigate sidewalks that had been shoveled with snow piled at the curbed, with no where for the water to drain.  To paraphrase the Wicked Witch of the West, "It's melting, it's melting."

Let k be the largest element of a particular collection of length n. We can show that k must always be less than or equal to n for all n > 2, and therefore the number of collections of length n of positive integers with sum = product is finite.

Define a and b for a collection such that a is the number of ones and b is the number of elements greater than one. So n = a + b.

The trivial cases where b = 0 or b = 1 have a small (finite) number of acceptable collections.

If b = 2, let the two largest elements in the collection be j and k. We see that a + j + k = j*k, which implies a = (k - 1)*(j - 1) - 1. Assuming k > n leads to the conclusion a > (n - 2), a contradiction. So k is less than or equal to n.

If b > 2, the sum of the collection is at most (b*k + a), and the product is at least k*[2^(b-1)]. Thus there would need to be a permissable value of a such that k*[2^(b-1) - b] is less than or equal to a. But if k > n this leads to a contradiction, because then k*[2^(b-1) - b] would be greater than n, and a cannot take on values this large. So again k must be less than or equal to n.

Since permissable values of k, the largest value in the collection, are always bounded by n for any fixed n (aside from a finite number of trivial cases), there are always a finite number of collections of any particular length.

This is like saying the driver is not responsible, buy the pedestrian is,  when he hits you while you are crossing on a green light.  The car is God.  Pedestrians be damned.  Pedestrians are just not important. So, forget cleaning the sidewalk.
I don't bother with any of this – I put on crampons.
The city takes care of the roadways because, as the city's entire worldview indicates, motor vehicle occupants are more important than non-occupants of motor vehicles.

Yak Trax are great for walking on ice, but are treacherous on ordinary surfaces, whether cleared sidewalks, or the floors in homes or stores. (I learned this from personal experience and from reading the instructions.) So while handy for ice fishing, they're not the solution for this urban problem.
The people who don't shovel the snow in front of their buildings probably do not read this paper.

Some of the problem here is figuring out who actually owns a property. You can't sue if you can't name ALL of the affected parties. You can't get into court if you can't serve notice of a lawsuit on the people you think are responsible for a property. And sometimes the answer is that no one actually owns a property. If someone dies intestate (without a will) and doesn't have any descendants at law then that house can literally sit until it falls apart and becomes a safety hazard. At which point the city should take the property into receivership (or the NY equivalent of receivership, I'm only familiar with the MA law on the subject), rehab it, and sell it off to the highest bidder. The same thing should be done for excessive snow removal tickets. The banks that foreclosed on these places would probably get their acts together if they knew that they could lose the right to the property over it.
The people who don't shovel in front of their buildings can't read this paper because it's buried in the snow in front of their buildings.

You people who don't shovel snow in front of your building be ready for lawsuits. If I fall and break something you can bet your life I'm going to bring a suit against you. I'm sick of these people who think they can own vacant property in this city and don't take responsibility for it. One such property is at the corner of 4th ave and 10th street. I hope you are at least getting tickets.

Perhaps other arab countries should share in trying to "figure out how to give the Palestinians enough room"...ie Jordan...why can't a Palestinian state include land on the east bank of the Jordan river as well?

Netanyahu came to the US to make a campaign speech in Israel. Timed it for evening broadcast in Israel.
Israelis will decide whether they want more of Netanyahu or not.
The US is a sovereign state and is doing its damnedest, as far as I can tell, to keep the door open with Iran. Talking is better than not talking.
The international situation has been dangerous since the end of WW II.
If India and Pakistan have managed to keep their fingers off the nuclear button despite violent disagreements, we can expect Iran to do the same. Talk, talk, talk.
Netanyahu should go home and try to figure out how to give the Palestinians enough room so that more Israelis and Palestinians don't have to die.
The world is crowded. Let the countries that think of themselves as the grown-ups in the room, act like grown-ups.
